p: Adolescents and young adults (AYA) ages 10–24 continue to be disproportionately burdened by the HIV epidemic. Globally, nearly one-third of new infections occur in young adults aged 15–24 years [1]. AYA in sub-Saharan African (SSA) experience particularly high HIV prevalence, accounting for 85% of all adolescents living with HIV [2]. Despite the high efficacy of oral antiretroviral therapy (ART) in preventing HIV-related morbidity and mortality, viral suppression among AYA living with HIV in SSA remains low [3], [4], [5], [6]. Sub-optimal adherence to ART is associated with poor clinical outcomes, including increased mortality [7], drug resistance [8], and onward transmission [ 9, 10].
